children: A 33-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus and diabetic kidney disease is evaluated in the emergency department for diabetic ketoacidosis.
Which of the following ECG findings is shown?

Hyperkalemia is responsible for the changes seen on this patient's ECG. This ECG demonstrates tall, peaked T waves, and flat P waves, which are characteristic of hyperkalemia. Although the correlation between ECG findings and degree of hyperkalemia may be variable, T-wave peaking often begins with mild to moderate elevations of potassium (5.5-7.0 mEq/L [5.5-7.0 mmol/L]) and tends to persist with more severe hyperkalemia. As potassium levels increase above 7.0 to 8.0 mEq/L (7.0-8.0 mmol/L), P-wave amplitude decreases and the QRS complex widens. With potassium levels above 9.0 to 10.0 mEq/L (9.0-10.0 mmol/L), the waveform will become sinusoidal, and cardiac arrest may follow.

objective.__html: Identify ECG changes characteristic of hyperkalemia.
